claim:
Consider the following background information: A researcher conducts multiple experiments to establish an infection and disease model for Clostridium perfringens in chickens. To ensure that all instruments are free of the pathogenic organism, he uses a disinfectant that oxidizes and denatures proteins.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: The researcher most likely used phenol as a disinfectant.

supporting.text: Phenol is not commonly used as a disinfectant in modern laboratory settings due to its toxicity and the availability of safer alternatives.

attacks.text: Phenol is not commonly used as a disinfectant in modern laboratory settings due to its toxicity and the availability of safer alternatives.
Phenol is still used in specific cases where its strong oxidizing properties are required, such as for highly resistant pathogens like Clostridium perfringens.
Modern alternatives like hydrogen peroxide or quaternary ammonium compounds are equally effective and safer, making phenol obsolete.
Historical data shows phenol was widely used for disinfection, and some labs may still rely on it due to established protocols.

supporting.text: The description of the disinfectant oxidizing and denaturing proteins is more characteristic of bleach (sodium hypochlorite) or hydrogen peroxide, not phenol.

attacks.text: The description of the disinfectant oxidizing and denaturing proteins is more characteristic of bleach (sodium hypochlorite) or hydrogen peroxide, not phenol.
Phenol can also denature proteins, though its primary mode of action is membrane disruption rather than oxidation.
Bleach and hydrogen peroxide are more commonly used in laboratory settings for their strong oxidizing properties, making them more likely candidates for ensuring sterility.

supporting.text: Phenol is less effective against spore-forming bacteria like Clostridium perfringens compared to oxidizing agents like bleach or hydrogen peroxide.

attacks.text: Phenol is less effective against spore-forming bacteria like Clostridium perfringens compared to oxidizing agents like bleach or hydrogen peroxide.
Phenol can still be effective at higher concentrations or prolonged exposure times, even against spore-forming bacteria.
Higher concentrations of phenol may be toxic or impractical for routine laboratory use.
Some strains of Clostridium perfringens may be more susceptible to phenol than others, depending on their specific spore coat composition.
Most clinical and laboratory strains of Clostridium perfringens show consistent resistance to phenol, making this exception rare.

supporting.text: Modern laboratory protocols for disinfecting instruments typically recommend the use of oxidizing agents or alcohol-based solutions, not phenol.

attacks.text: Modern laboratory protocols for disinfecting instruments typically recommend the use of oxidizing agents or alcohol-based solutions, not phenol.
Phenol is still used in some laboratory settings due to its effectiveness against certain resistant organisms.
The use of phenol has declined significantly due to its toxicity and the availability of safer alternatives.
Oxidizing agents like hydrogen peroxide are more effective against Clostridium perfringens than phenol.
